citeinfo.origin: U.S. Navy, Office of Naval Research and Charlie Eriksen, University of Washington (UW), School of Oceanography
citeinfo.title: Glider Surveys of the Japan/East Sea Circulation

abstract.p: The investigator will use small, autonomous underwater vehicles (gliders) to delineate the subpolar front and to make time series observations and repeat cross-sections at the front.

Four gliders will be deployed off Korea, allowed to seek and transit to their duty stations in the front, collect data in the front, and then seek and transit to a recovery point off Japan. The T-S profiles thus collected will be analyzed to study the dynamics of the front. No large research vessels are necessary.
International Collaborators: Prof. Kuh Kim (Seoul National University, Korea), Prof. Masaki Takematsu (RIAM, Kyushu National University), and Prof. J.-H. Yoon (RIAM, Kyushu National University).
Part of the U.S. Office of Naval Research (ONR) supported research in the Japan/East Sea (JES) during 1998-2000. JES website URL: http://sam.ucsd.edu/onr_jes/onr_jes.html

descript.purpose: To describe the subpolar frontal circulation in the Japan/East Sea.
